comments.text:
Build identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:7.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/7.0.1

Currently, the user is not able to delete apps from the Dashboard. The only way to delete apps is to go to about:apps.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Launch Firefox
2. Install the open web apps extension - Can be found here: http://people.mozilla.com/~mdabbagh/openwebapps/extension/openwebapps_01112011.xpi
3. Go to https://apps.mozillalabs.com/appdir/
4. Install an app
5. Go to https://myapps.mozillalabs.com/

Expected Results:
User is able to delete an app from the Dashboard

Actual Results:
There is no way to delete apps from the Dashboard. The user can only launch apps.

comments.text:
Thanks Bill, it seems that works. I didn't know this functionality existed, is there somewhere where this is mentioned/described along with other features of the Dashboard? 

I'm a little concerned about how intuitive this functionality is for the average user. Is there some way that we can make it clearer to the user as to how they can delete an app? Maybe have the 'X' as a permanent part of the icon or write a note or tool-tip that explains how they can do this? On mobile, holding down on an icon to delete it seems more natural but on desktop, it feels a little out of place.

Thanks!

comments.text: On desktop we're probably going to want a timed hover option for removing the application, that's the equivalent operation to a long touch on mobile.  (Where timed hover is a 5 second hover that eventually reveals the (X) button)  Also we'll likely want a right click option for the desktop as well.  Not exactly what Chrome is doing but something similar: http://cl.ly/2i130J0u1B0g2L362D0i

comments.author: deletesoftware+moz@yandex.ru
comments.raw_text: The current method deletion is also difficult to use with a graphics tablet, because of the "no movement" requirement.

> Where timed hover is a 5 second hover that eventually reveals the (X) button)

Did you mean 5 milliseconds? If not, I'm not sure it's much more intuitive than the current click-and-hold-for-a-while.

Since there doesn't seem to exist a cross-platform usual practice for this, why not work with something that needs no guess work, like your hover suggestion minus the 5-second delay?

Right-click sounds pretty standard and easy too.

Since there doesn't seem to exist a cross-platform usual practice for this, why not work with something that needs no guess work, like your hover suggestion minus the 5-second delay?

Right-click sounds pretty standard and easy too.

(In reply to Aleksej [:Aleksej] from comment #6)
> The current method deletion is also difficult to use with a graphics tablet,
> because of the "no movement" requirement.

Clarification:
* when "clicking" the icon, the pointer almost certainly will move a little, so the current UI won’t recognize the action as a deletion request.
* motionless hovering is easy with a tablet, but not precisely at the point of the user’s choice, because the tablet can track movements of the pen tip hovering over a centimeter above it.
